caption: TABLE I: Comparison with baseline on COCO val2017. We report the number of parameters and FLOPs of the backbone. Underline indicates FLOPs or metrics on par with the baseline. APbsuperscriptAPb\rm AP^{b}roman_AP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and APmsuperscriptAPm\rm AP^{m}roman_AP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent box AP and mask AP, respectively.
description: Table I presents a comparison of the proposed Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid Networks (PIIP) model with baseline models on the COCO val2017 dataset for object detection.  The table shows the number of parameters and floating point operations (FLOPs) for each backbone model.  Key performance metrics include Average Precision for bounding boxes (APb) and Average Precision for masks (APm), calculated at different Intersection over Union (IoU) thresholds (0.5, 0.75).  Underlined values in the FLOPs and AP columns indicate that the PIIP model achieves comparable or better results than the baseline models with a lower computational cost.

caption: TABLE II: Performance of CNN-based and heterogeneous models on COCO val2017.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of different model architectures on the COCO val2017 dataset.  It compares models built using only CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks), models using a heterogeneous combination of CNNs and ViTs (Vision Transformers), and a baseline ViTDet-B model. The comparison is based on the number of branches used in the model architecture, resolution, and the resulting APb (Average Precision for bounding boxes) and APm (Average Precision for masks) metrics from the Mask R-CNN 1× schedule. The table aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid Network (PIIP) approach by showing how it can achieve better performance with lower computational costs compared to other approaches.

caption:
TABLE III: Object detection and instance segmentation performance on COCO val2017. ‘MS’ means using AutoAugment [71] for multi-scale training. Large-size models use ViT weights trained on ImageNet-21K.
Some results are from [21].
description: Table III presents a comparison of different models' performance on the COCO val2017 dataset for object detection and instance segmentation tasks.  The table shows the Average Precision (AP) scores at different Intersection over Union (IoU) thresholds (AP50, AP75, AP, APm).  The models compared include various vision transformers (ViTs) and other architectures, highlighting the impact of different model architectures on performance.  The 'MS' column indicates whether the model was trained using AutoAugment [71] for multi-scale training, a data augmentation technique to improve model robustness and generalization. Large-size models are trained using ViT weights pretrained on ImageNet-21K, a larger and more diverse image dataset, than the standard ImageNet. Some results are taken from the literature [21], allowing comparison with previous state-of-the-art methods.

caption: TABLE IV: Experiments on the large-scale vision foundation model InternViT-6B.
description: This table presents the results of experiments conducted using the InternViT-6B, a large-scale vision foundation model.  It compares the performance of the baseline InternViT-6B model against the proposed PIIP (Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid) method across different experimental settings. The comparison focuses on object detection and semantic segmentation metrics, including average precision (AP), mask average precision (APm), and the number of floating point operations (FLOPs).  Various configurations of PIIP are tested, differing in the number of branches and the resolution of input images, to showcase the impact of the PIIP architecture on computational efficiency and performance gains. Crop Size and UperNet 160k metrics are also provided for semantic segmentation.

caption: TABLE X: From-scratch pre-training settings and results on ImageNet-1K.
description: This table details the configuration and performance of a model trained from scratch using a parameter-inverted image pyramid design.  It breaks down the model architecture, showing the number of layers, dimensions, heads, resolution, parameters, and FLOPS for each branch (three branches are used in this architecture). The table also reports the model's top-1 accuracy on the ImageNet-1K dataset, offering a comparison between a standard ViT-B model and the proposed PIIP-B model.

caption: TABLE XI: Comparison with multi-resolution baselines on multimodal benchmarks. All models are trained with LLaVA-1.5 [24] training data. We report #FLOPs of the vision encoder.
description: This table compares the performance of different image processing models on various multimodal benchmarks.  All models were trained using the same LLaVA-1.5 training data for consistency. The key metric is performance on the benchmarks, which assesses the models' ability to understand and process information from both text and images. The table also provides the FLOPs (floating point operations) for the vision encoder component of each model.  This value indicates the computational cost associated with the image processing part of each model, allowing for a comparison of efficiency in addition to performance.

caption:
TABLE XII: 
Comparison with existing MLLMs on multimodal benchmarks.
“Data” denotes the data size of all training stages.
*Images from SQA-IMG test set are observed in training, so we mark its result and Avg in gray.
description: Table XII presents a comparison of the PIIP-LLaVA model's performance against other state-of-the-art multimodal large language models (MLLMs) across various benchmark datasets.  These benchmarks assess different aspects of multimodal understanding, including perception, cognition, and visual question answering. The table details each model's performance metrics (MMBEN, MMVet, TextVQA, SQA, GQA, VQAv2, SEED, POPE, and Avg.), the vision encoder used, the resolution of the input images, the size of the language model, and the amount of training data used.  A key aspect highlighted is that some models had access to images from the SQA-IMG test set during training; these results (marked with *) are presented in gray to emphasize the potential bias involved in their performance.

caption: TABLE XIII: Ablation on multimodal understanding with CLIP-B, CLIP-L and Vicuna-7B.
description: This table presents the results of ablation studies on the PIIP-LLaVA model for multimodal understanding.  It investigates the impact of different numbers of cross-branch interactions and the extent to which different parts of the vision encoder (branches and interaction modules) are frozen during the pretraining phase. The results are evaluated across several key multimodal understanding benchmarks.  The table shows how changes in the model's architecture affect performance on various tasks, allowing for an understanding of the impact of different design choices on the overall effectiveness of the model.

caption: TABLE XIV: Ablation on image pyramid and parameter-inverted design. ‘PI’, ‘IP’ and ‘Inter.’ represent parameter-inverted, image pyramid and interactions. ‘MS’ means multi-scale training, following [71].
description: This table presents an ablation study comparing different image pyramid designs and their impact on object detection performance using the Mask R-CNN model. It systematically varies the presence or absence of parameter-inverted design ('PI'), image pyramids ('IP'), and cross-branch interactions ('Inter.'), with and without multi-scale training ('MS').  The results show the effects of these design choices on the model's accuracy (APb, APm, AP50, AP75) in terms of object detection.  Different configurations are shown, some using only one resolution, others with multi-resolution inputs, ranging from a single-branch to 3-branch and 4-branch models of different sizes.

caption: TABLE XV: Baseline with higher resolution.
description: This table compares the performance of the ViTDet-L model (a baseline vision transformer object detection model) at different input image resolutions.  It shows the model's parameters, FLOPs (floating point operations), and box Average Precision (APb) at resolutions of 1024 and 1792 pixels. It also includes results for the PIIP-TSBL model (the proposed Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid Network), demonstrating its performance against the baseline at a higher resolution (1792 pixels). The comparison helps to assess the efficiency and effectiveness of the PIIP-TSBL model in object detection.

caption: TABLE XVI: Ablation on attention implementation and number of interactions with PIIP-TSB 1120/896/448.
description: This table presents the results of ablation studies conducted on the PIIP-TSB model (with resolution 1120/896/448) to analyze the impact of different attention mechanisms (regular vs. deformable) and varying numbers of cross-branch interactions on object detection performance.  For each combination of attention type and interaction count, the table reports the number of FLOPs (floating point operations), and the performance metrics AP (average precision) broken down by different object sizes (small, medium, large). This allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the trade-off between computational cost and detection accuracy.

content:
Model Resolution #Param #FLOPs Top-1 Acc
ViT-B (our impl.) 224 86M 17.5G 82.0
PIIP-B (ours) 512/256/128 100M 18.4G 82.7
caption: TABLE XVII: Ablation on interaction directions with PIIP-TSB under resolution 1120/896/448.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on different interaction directions within the PIIP-TSB model, specifically focusing on how various interaction patterns between branches affect model performance. The study was conducted using a specific resolution (1120/896/448) for the input images. Different interaction types are compared, each denoted by a unique label (Type1-Type5), and their respective performance metrics (APb and APm) and computational cost (FLOPs) are reported. This allows for a quantitative comparison of the effectiveness and efficiency of different approaches for multi-scale feature interaction within the PIIP architecture.
